revisions.rev:
{{Infobox person |name =Greg Kinnear |image =Gregkinnear06.jpg |caption =Greg Kinnear in May 2006 |birth_name =Gregory Kinnear |birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1963|6|17}} |birth_place =[[Logansport, Indiana]], U.S. |death_date = |occupation = Actor/TV personality |years_active = 1988âpresent |spouse = Helen Labdon (1999âpresent) }} '''Gregory''' "'''Greg'''" '''Kinnear''' (born June 17, 1963) is an American actor and television personality who first rose to stardom in 1991. He has appeared in more than 20 motion pictures, and was nominated for an [[Academy Award]] for his role in ''[[As Good as It Gets]]''. ==Early life== Kinnear was born in [[Logansport, Indiana]], the son of Suzanne, a homemaker, and Edward Kinnear, a career diplomat who worked for the [[State Department|US State Department]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/84/Greg-Kinnear.html |title=Greg Kinnear Biography (1963â) |publisher=Filmreference.com |accessdate=2008-10-28}}{{cite web|url=http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800019194/bio |title=Greg Kinnear Biography |publisher=Movies.yahoo.com |accessdate=2008-10-28}} He has two brothers, James and Steven. When he was a child, the Kinnear family moved around frequently, from [[Beirut]] to [[Athens]], part of a group sometimes referred to as the "[[Foreign Service Brat]]s". While a student at the [[American Community Schools]] in Athens, Greg Kinnear first ventured into the role of talk show host with his radio show "School Daze With Greg Kinnear". Returning to the United States for a college education, he attended the [[University of Arizona]], where he graduated in 1985 with a degree in [[broadcast journalism]]. At Arizona, Greg was a member of the [[Alpha Tau Omega]] Fraternity.http://www.ato.org/alphatauomega/atohistory/FamousATOs.aspx ==Career== {{unreferenced|section|date=October 2011}} ===Talk shows=== Kinnear hosted a short-lived [[game show]], ''[[College Mad House]]'', which was spun off from the kids' show, ''[[Fun House (game show)|Fun House]]''. Later he would become the creator, co-executive producer, and host of ''[[Best of the Worst]]'' which aired from 1990 to 1991. In 1991, Kinnear became the first host of ''[[Talk Soup]]'', which he did until 1995, when he left the show for the [[NBC]] late-night talk show, ''[[Later with Greg Kinnear]]'' (1994). ===Film roles=== {{unreferenced|section|date=October 2011}} It was in 1994 that Kinnear had his first big screen role, as a talk show host in the [[Damon Wayans]] comedy ''[[Blankman]]''. In 1995 he won the part of David Larrabee in [[Sydney Pollack]]'s remake of [[Billy Wilder]]'s 1954 classic ''[[Sabrina (1995 film)|Sabrina]]''. He later played the lead role in the 1996 comedy ''[[Dear God (film)|Dear God]]''. In 1997, he was cast in [[James L. Brooks]]' comedy-drama, ''[[As Good as It Gets]]'', for which he received a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]]. His next film, ''[[A Smile Like Yours]]'', had him starring opposite [[Lauren Holly]] as part of a couple trying to have a baby. His next film was the popular ''[[You've Got Mail]]'', in which he played [[Meg Ryan]]'s significant other. His following films were ''[[Mystery Men]]'', ''[[Nurse Betty]]'', ''[[Loser (film)|Loser]]'', ''[[The Gift (2000 film)|The Gift]]'', and ''[[Someone Like You (film)|Someone Like You]]''. Kinnear often alternated roles, often playing good guys like a playboy in ''[[Sabrina (1995 film)|Sabrina]]'' or a gay painter in ''[[As Good as It Gets]]'', to bad guys such as a sleazy college professor in ''[[Loser (film)|Loser]]'' and an egotistical soap opera star in ''[[Nurse Betty]]''. In 2002, Kinnear starred in the movie ''[[Auto Focus]]'' about the life and murder of actor [[Bob Crane]]. In 2003 he starred in ''[[Stuck on You (film)|Stuck On You]]'', a comedy in which he played opposite [[Matt Damon]] as a conjoined twin who pursues his dream of becoming a Hollywood actor in spite of his joined brother's desire for a different kind of life. In 2005 he starred in the black comedy ''[[The Matador]]'' opposite [[Pierce Brosnan]] and voiced the main antagonist, [[Ratchet]] in the compter-animated film ''[[Robots (film)|Robots]]''. In 2006, Kinnear co-starred with [[Steve Carell]] in the [[Academy Award|Oscar-winning]] comedy-drama ''[[Little Miss Sunshine]]'', and with [[Mark Wahlberg]] in ''[[Invincible (2006 film)|Invincible]]'', based on the true story of a bartender who tries out for the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] football team. He also appeared in ''[[Fast Food Nation (film)|Fast Food Nation]]'', playing a [[fast food]] executive who discovers secrets about his company. In 2008 starred in the movie ''[[Flash of Genius (film)|Flash of Genius]]'', a docudrama about [[Robert Kearns]] who invented the intermittent windshield wiper. His portrayal of then-Major [[Bruce P. Crandall]] in 2002's ''[[We Were Soldiers]]'' brought public attention to Crandall's heroism during the 1965 [[Battle of Ia Drang]]. (On February 26, 2007, Crandall was awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] by [[George W. Bush|President Bush]].) Greg also appeared in the movie ''[[Baby Mama]]'' with Tina Fey and Amy Poehler. He played a man working in a local smoothie shop and sparked a romantic interest in Tina Fey's character. In 2010, Kinnear starred as the estranged father of [[Miley Cyrus]]' character in ''[[The Last Song (film)|The Last Song]]''. In 2011, Kinnear starred in the miniseries ''[[The Kennedys (TV miniseries)|The Kennedys]]'' playing the lead role as [[John F. Kennedy]]. It was originally planned to air on the [[The History Channel|History Channel]], however, it was announced in January 2011 that the miniseries had been pulled from that network.http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/caroline-kennedy-maria-shriver-helped-69764/The Hollywood Reporter.aspx It was subsequently picked up by [[ReelzChannel]] and then first aired on April 3, 2011. ==Personal life== Kinnear married [[United Kingdom|British]] model Helen Labdon in 1999. Labdon was previously a former [[Page Three|Page 3]] [[glamour model]].{{cite web|url=http://www.page3.com/girl/helen_labdon/biog.shtml|title=Helen Labdon Biography, Page3.com (contains nudity)|publisher=The Sun|accessdate=2009-08-01}} They have three daughters, Lily Katherine (born September 2003), Audrey Mae (born June 2006) and Kate "Katie" Grace (born fall 2009). ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" !
